content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment:

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Reapproving.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Reapproving

Just resubmitted again; for your convenience most important info in this new comment: 
You can see some of the work on this contribution in below comments; based on those comments and other communications, with help of @Timinator the statement has been carefully crafted, and the cases haven been chosen to cover truly all (!) possible options of the 24-game (and to even go beyond it).

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice puzzle. It definitely deserves its hard difficulty for the large number of steps and edge cases. The large variety of test cases was sufficient to catch every issue I tried for two different approaches to solving it.

The validation period is about to expire but I'll reapprove the puzzle if you repost it.
nice
nice game
Very good
Love the idea, hope to see it published!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Re-approving. See previous comments.

Just resubmitted again; for your convenience most important info in this new comment: 
You can see some of the work on this contribution in below comments; based on those comments and other communications, with help of @Timinator the statement has been carefully crafted, and the cases haven been chosen to cover truly all (!) possible options of the 24-game (and to even go beyond it).

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)
Approved the contribution.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is one of the most thought-provoking puzzles I've done in a long time. It is nothing more than basic arithmetic. Given a piece of paper and a pencil, any one of us could easily rearrange these expressions to the asked for standard form in no more than probably 2 minutes per expression. It should be easy enough to distinguish the steps of that process and articulate those steps in the form of an algorithm, right? ... Right? ... You might be surprised how much we all take basic arithmetic for granted.

The author's attention to detail in test case development is absolutely outstanding. The overall concept and design of the puzzle are superb. This is a wonderful opportunity to take the 24 Game to a whole new level and truly explore articulating your understanding of arithmetic as an algorithm!

This contribution was in 'Ready' before, but now it is *much more ready*. You can see some of the work on this contribution in below comments; based on those comments and other communications, with help of @Timinator the statement has been thoroughly revised, and the cases haven been chosen to now cover truly all (!) possible options of the 24-game (and to even go beyond it).

The "24 Game" test case is quite challenging. I'm finding a handful of solutions you are not finding. Do you see anything wrong with these:

(24+24)/1-24
24+1*(24-24)

I am 75% complete with this puzzle. I fully support the "hard" label and I fully support this puzzle as a unique contribution compared to the original 24 Game puzzle. The complexity in finding only unique solutions and distinguishing rules so that those unique solutions can be objectively validated is a strong addition to this challenge.

I read the problem statement. Conclusion - this is not quite a 24 game! This is something incomprehensible about sorting mathematical expressions according to 7 rules. I find it difficult to assess this.

There is already a 24 game puzzle on CodinGame, although the output requirements are different:

https://www.codingame.com/training/medium/24-game

So, please at least change the title so that if your puzzle is approved, there won't be two puzzles of the same name.

I'm not sure whether your puzzle is sufficiently unique... I'd like to see other approvers' opinions.

For reference, there are also these two puzzles on the same theme of adding operators to some numbers for a given result:

https://www.codingame.com/training/medium/find-the-missing-plus-signs-in-addition

https://www.codingame.com/training/hard/the-total-is-right---weird-edition

Minor issue (I haven't read the statement in detail yet): Please format ns as a variable (2 times) in Output section.

Thanks.

Ohh that's stupid of me, I did not check that. I'll check out those other puzzles and most likely withdraw mine. Anyway, I had fun solving my own puzzle the last two weeks :-).

On second thought (but leaving my first thought hanging here as well), after quickly checking the description of those other puzzles:
- The other 24 game is easier in set-up: you simply have to check whether it is possible or not. (NB, I remember you saying something about binary output on my Clash-of-code 24-game submission)
- Fair point that techniques for the puzzle I propose are also partly covered in those other two puzzles.
I did have however fun in having to combine all those tools, and discovering along the way that each time it was not yet perfect. Knowing the 24-game, the premise was easy (I want to know all unique solutions), but it proved a real puzzle to get there. This is less so the case with the puzzles you referred to. Possibly, other codingamers would also enjoy to go 'all the way' on this one.

So, as you suggested, I am also going to await other approvers' opinions on the uniqueness. But, I will anyway shift the difficulty of this one to 'hard' (it is clearly more difficult than the medium 24-game puzzle you referred to), and I will change the name.

Indeed, besides finding a solution to the 24 game, the bigger challenge is rewriting equations. The seven rules possibly can be written very different (and easier), hopefully some of the community can help with that. But, what it basically comes done to, is to get unique solutions only (eg: 1*(2*3*4) is *of course* the same as 1*2*3*4, and 30-(1+2+3) is *of course* the same as 30-1-2-3, and as 30-3-2-1, ...). Such rewriting comes naturally to us on paper, but by putting it in rules I ended up with those 7. Hopefully some with background in mathematics (or common sense) can help me with rephrasing/rewriting so that it becomes comprehensible :-).

EDIT: I turned it into five rules now, hopefully it is becoming more comprehensible.

Thanks a lot for your nice feedback! Good to hear that someone else also finds it hard - I had quite a hard time myself with getting the solution.

If you say you are 75% complete, could you also say something about the order of the test/validator cases? A fresh pair of eyes like yours might have a good view on what the range in difficulty is - whether the cases increase in difficulty, or whether the order of some cases could better be changed.

And how is this puzzle regarding error solving; is it difficult for you to get a grasp on which 25% you are missing - and if that is difficult, do you have any suggestions on how that could be helped?

In any case thanks for taking your time to try this puzzle.

I like this for a "division" test case:

96 1 2 2

My solution still needs a little work because I didn't pay enough attention to the rules. Your solution comes up with 7 unique expressions, two of which are:

96/(2+2)/1
96/1/(2+2)

Aren't these identical? Shouldn't the parentheses be pushed to the back, making only the second expression valid?
Awesome to hear, thanks a lot!
Thanks! Are you also able to approve it through the approval system? :-)
Thanks for the support :-). No plans to approve it yourself, by any chance?
Thanks! Any time / interest to solve and approve this contribution? :-)
Awesome, thanks for taking your time approving it! Just one more needed:-).
I understand you've commented here before, but please still provide the reason(s) when you approve or reject contributions. Thank you.

Sorry, I thought it was optional.

Some years ago, a problem sharing some similarities with this one was presented on the Numberphile channel (if I recall correctly). I spent hours on this subject: trying to mix numerics with path finders. 

Here, the problem is well exposed ; tests cases and examples are pertinent. I find it interesting, so I approve.

Do I need to speak more on this?
Thanks!
Just reposted, thanks in advance for reapproving.
Finally got the level 20 to be able to approve :)
Very nice that you came back here to approve, thanks a lot! :-)

Those are two very good points; I changed my solution code and added the suggested case.
- The two cases of the 24-game were not part of my solutions because I lazily had programmed that brackets could be removed if the result with or without brackets is exactly the same. And, indeed, (24+24)/1-24 == 24+24/1-24. However, I do not like this, so I will change this; I agree with you that those are unique solutions. The 24-game test jumped from 12 to 18 unique solutions. Very good found, apologies for the confusion!
- The division test case is a very good find; shifting the parentheses to the back in that situation was not yet part of my code, because I had not yet encountered that situation, so thanks for pointing it out. I've now added it as a test case, and changed my solution code so that indeed only 96/1/(2+2) is kept.

You found two good edge cases; it needed two changes in my solution code, but it only led to different results on those specific cases (the outcome for all other cases is still the same) - so these were truly (and relevant) edge cases, thanks!

Looks good! I am passing everything now except the new Validator 9. Your solution says this is a valid expression:

96/8+2*6

The rule in question I believe is: Two similar parts, separated by multiplication or addition, should be sorted according to their value in ascending order.

I don't consider 96/8 and 2*6 to be "similar parts", so I am changing the expression to:

2*6+96/8

Even if you consider them similar parts, they have equal value, so the string starting with 2 comes before the string starting with 9, right?

I think as many test cases as possible that generate a significant number of unique expressions is important...and just plain fun to see. Here is a good one I found:

2 3 6 12

I think you should add this one too. I just ran it and found significant errors in my code:

1 13 1 11

Cool cool cool. I've pulled the puzzle back in WIP, because I like your thinking. The coming days I'll go over the unique solutions so far covered in the cases with respect to their parentheses/operator sequence, and add some cases covering situations still missing. Because, while we are at it, why not cover it all.

As for the 2*6+96/8 case: that was a mistake in my code as well. In one of the last stages of code development I moved the replacing of a/b/c/d with the actual values fully to the end of the script - but because of that, the string-comparison of the two parts was not based on the values, but based on the letters a/b/c/d (so, in that case, it compared like a/d+b*d -> 96/8+2*6). I've resolved the mistake, now it gives indeed 2*6+96/8, as it should.

I think you and I are almost completely on the same page. I just need to clarify one thing. Does Rule 4: Similar Parts ever apply to the following?

(a+b)*(c-d)
(a-b)*(c+d)
a/b+c*d
a*d+c/d

Your explanation above makes it sound like you do consider these examples to have "similar parts", but my vote is that they are not similar parts because the operators in the parts do not match. To me, similar parts should have identical operators, otherwise the parts can be sorted by operator. If that were true, only when the operators in the parts are identical would Rule 4 come into play.

NB: is there some private message option in Codingame? I could not find it, so I just keep the discussion live here.

I have worked myself through all parentheses/operator combinations; based on that I found two issues that I now have resolved:
- I had not yet decided earlier on a-b-c*d (or c/d) vs a-c*d-b; I have now decided to include that under rule five (division latest as much as possible -> a-c*d-b). This case is covered by the 'Extra 2' test.
- I had not explicitly decided on the (a-b)*(c-d) sorting case - I have for now decided (against your vote) to extent the reach of rule 4 to all (a+-b)*(c+-d) and a/*b+c/*d cases. I opt against operator sorting in those cases for now, because that would either require an additional rule, or it would require to become part of rule 5 - but then the order of the rules needs to be changed (because, at this moment, I see rule 5 as 'in any other case', while with also extending it to the ()*() or ..+.. cases it would interfere a bit with the territory of rule 4). 

I've rephrased the statement a bit, which hopefully describes those matters clearly. While for now I opted against your vote, feel free to change my mind - most importantly there need to be consistent rules, precisely what those rules are is a bit arbitrary.

Based on my parentheses/operator administration, there are still 39 situations not covered (but, on trying them, my current code resolves them all according to the rules). On my to-do list is to add a couple of cases that efficiently cover a bunch of those, but I have decided not to aim to cover ALL, because there are quite some combinations for which the four values only have that single combination as solution (so, that would require to add +20 cases, eg 10 tests and 10 validators,, which I think is a bit too much). Apart from adding 2-3 cases that cover multiple of the as of yet not present, I will add one or more cases concerning the latest edges we found (the a-c*d-b sorting, and a couple of different situations for which rule 4 applies).

After having added the cases, I will carefully check the order of cases again. I'd prefer to have the 24-game case as final case (in the spirit of the game), but it might not be the hardest one anymore.
That all sounds reasonable to me. I'll take another look at it all this weekend and change my code to handle the rules as is.
I will send a PM in the Forum in case you'd prefer to communicate a few things over there.

I'm almost finished now. I just have a few edge case division issues. The test cases are great and the order works just fine for me. Here's what this puzzle has taught me. We all know how to simplify equations, but I'll bet most of us completely take those steps for granted. In order to have multiple solutions, you must have those rules so that the puzzler can generate the same output the validator is looking for. Shouldn't be too tough, right? Wrong! 

I find the complexity of this seemingly simple exercises wonderfully challenging. Right now, I think the puzzle is darn good as is. After I finish, I'll go through the goal statement in more detail and see if I have any suggestions, but for now, great job!

That's awesome to hear, thanks! While some puzzles might be designed by people that know exactly what they are creating, with this one I went through the exact same lesson as you. I started of with a clash, but along the way I discovered more and more rewriting that I would do on paper in a wink,, but that proved to have various complexities (for me) in code. And I actually discovered while working on this that several '24-game solver'-websites also find it complex - they either give all non-unique solutions, or simply the first x solutions, or seemingly unique but not as far rewritten as in this puzzle.

Hi @About, if you are interested to assess again; the first version of this puzzle you found incomprehensible, and you were maybe led to believe that you would be doing the 24-game, while instead you were required to rewrite expressions. @Timinator and I have fully revised the statement. While the puzzle is still very much about sorting and rewriting, at least the statement is honest about this now, and we brought it back to three rules instead of the incomprehensible 7 while you tried to assess the first time. 

I'm curious whether the changes made it more comprehensible for you.
I think it got better. I can understand the rules. I just don't really like parsing expressions. You don't have to worry about it!

Ah that makes sense - I'm not so sure whether I like it either. Possibly, if before starting on the puzzle I had realized that it took so many parsing, I would not even have started it. I naively started on it and along the way discovered more and more complexities, and soon had put so much time in it that it felt a shame not to finish.

Anyway thanks for the reply!

I've just taken some time to read the statement in detail. Below are my comments:

Goal section
* Suggest to change all references to "equation" to "expression" because there must be an equals sign in an equation. (Reference: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equation )

* Paragraph 1: Suggest to add "so that the end result is 24" after "must be used".

* Paragraph 1: Suggest to add "The given numbers may be rearranged in any order; that is, the original order need not be followed."

* Paragraph 1: Suggest to change "For the 24 game" to "Normally".

* Rule 1: Please change "little" to "few".

* Rule 2: Suggest to change "backwards" to "at a later position".

* Rule 2: In the example, the first pair of parentheses is not needed (i.e. (3+4)*3+3 and 3+3*(3+4) ).

* Rule 3: Please add "in ascending order".

* Rule 3: Do you mean "same" instead of "similar"?

* Rule 3: Suggest to change "happen" to "apply".

* Rule 3: The examples of the last point are not valid because the parentheses are not needed.

* Rule 4: Please add "in ascending order".

* Example: Suggest to change "->" to "→".

* Example: Suggest to change "backwards" to "at a later position".

* Example: Please change "less" to "fewer".

* Example: You typed 3*(2*5)-2 as the last solution. Please fix it.

* Sorting multiple unique solutions: Is it possible to change the example? All the parenthesis in "a+((b+c)+d))" may be removed.

Input section
* Please add "space-separated".

Output section
* Please change "equation" to "expressions".

Title
* The current title is fine, but it is kind of dull :P I don't have any excellent ideas yet. The first ones that come to my mind are "24 All the Way" and "24, Get 'Em All!" And of course, it's fine if you choose not to change the title :)

Thanks.

Thanks as usual, but extra thanks for this one; I am curious whether at the end it will get approval, but you definitely are a big help to giving it the best shot. I've implemented all your suggestions. As for the title, good point, it can be more interesting. I did change it now, but are still not fully satisfied with it; I might change it later on when a better idea comes to mind.

While I have your attention, let me ask you another question:
- I think with the current output, error solving might be challenging (if you simply find too much solutions, you will only see that you have the wrong number, but you do not yet get info on precisely which expression(s) you need to change). I am thinking whether it would be better to turn the output into one line (so, ns and the expressions comma+space separated, like '2: 2*2*2*3, 2*3*(2+2)', or to simply put all answers in the statement. Any opinion on that?

Thank you for your comment :D

First about your question: When I was typing my previous comment, I actually had thought about suggesting to output the unique solutions directly without the need to output the number of solutions. But then I realised that it would be useful to compare that number first, so I didn't suggest that.

And back to your question: As the first possible error a player may make may very well be the number of solutions, it does not really matter whether the solutions are output by line or comma-separated.

The output format may or may not help if the error made is the solutions themselves (e.g. wrong order or not removing unnecessary parenthesis). I mean, it's easier to debug to compare in full, whereas CG's error stream just shows the point at which the actual output starts to differ from the expected output.

Also, as this is a Hard puzzle, I believe the player will be experienced enough to understand where they can look up the full expected output in the appropriate place. Outputting all the solutions by separating them with commas does not look good. It may be even harder to read when trying to debug offline.

So, my feeling is that the current output format is good as it is.

I've got a few comments after a fresh look at the revised version:

Goal section
* The very first example of 3+(6*5-9): maybe change it to another example that really needs parenthesis?

* Rule 1: Suggest to change the example from 3*4*5*6 to 1*2*3*4 so that it also evaluates to 24 :wink:

* Sorting multiple unique solutions: You don't need the outer set of parenthesis in "a+((b+c)/d))". Is there really an example of this rule? It seems that no output in any test or validator requires overlapping parenthesis. (Also, the parenthesis are not balanced in the example :P)

Input section
* Please delete the space character in "space -separated".

Title
Wow, game over, haha. Some more suggestions for your consideration: "24 Mega Game", "Super 24 Game".

By the way, it usually takes a longer time to get a Hard game reviewed, tested and approved, so be prepared that it may be on the pending list for a few months.

Thanks.

- Ok, I'll leave the output as it is for now, thanks for weighing in!
- I have changed the incorrect / too much parentheses / not evaluating to 24 examples.
- On sorting, and the case of overlapping parentheses: indeed, the example I gave is bad, in none of my tests/validators this case happens, and I cannot think of any good example. In fact, all examples in which I accidentally used this, could be rewritten to less parentheses. It probably has to do with something like this: brackets are only needed when */ are mixed with +-. However, mixing highest level +-and lower level */ also does not require brackets [3+(3*3) is simply 3+3*3]. A situation of overlapping brackets would imply three levels [L1(L2(L3))], but you cannot create three levels without having at least once +- -> */. So, always on one of the levels the brackets can be removed [Either a+(b*(c+d)) -> a+b*(c+d) or a*(b+(c*d)) -> a*(b+c*d)]. Probably someone with a proper background in mathematics can explain this much better.
But, long story short, this means that probably all those situations can be skipped from my solution code as well (i.e. I struggled on some parts that were not needed at all :-)).
Actually, I just tested it (in my code, I've distinguished 11 bracket situations, but situations 2,3,8,9 are those with overlap): not evaluating those situations gives exactly the same result (*of course*). EDIT: just changed the solution code accordingly, it now works with 7 distinct bracket cases.
- Title: if I have multiple months anyway, hopefully I will come up with a better one. Thanks for the heads up on the review time, I'll try to curb my impatience.

Good, no more issues found for now :wink:

And I like the current title better than the previous ones :D
Hi 5DN1L: Timinator and I have thoroughly revised the statement. I would appreciate it a lot if your sharp eyes go over it once more.

Thank you for the invitation to review! Here are my comments:

* Rule 3b: Please delete the extra left bracket in the second example.

* Example of 2,2,3,5: Rule 3b also applies when rewriting ((5*2)-2)*3→3*(2*5-2).

* Suggest to change the following examples so that the expressions equal 24:
  • Definition of subexpression: (1+2)*(3-4) => (1+2)*(9-1)
  • Rule 2: 3*(5-3+7) => 3*(5-4+7)
  • Rule 3c: 2*4+1*3 => 4*5+2*2

* Rule 3c: is the part "In the case of equal value, sort the subexpressions as strings" covered in any of the existing tests and validators?

Also, is the said sorting order the same as the one described under the heading "SORTING MULTIPLE UNIQUE SOLUTIONS"? If so, please state so in the statement.

Thanks a lot! Changed all accordingly. As for your question: the sorting as strings I have just added as a test case.  One of the reasons this puzzle is still in WIP, is that I am planning to add 2-3 more test cases to cover as much as possible unique parentheses/operator combinations, and to doublecheck that all rule cases are covered at least once. After I have all the test cases, I will reorder them.
